questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
On further interview, it was revealed that the patient used to stargaze as a child, sometimes staring at the sun for several hours at a time without any special protective lens. 

Which of the following describes the classical findings associated with solar retinopathy in multimodal retinal imaging?

answers.answerText: A. Disruption of ellipsoid zone and retinal pigmented epithelium on OCT macula
B. A central punctate area of hyper-autofluorescence on fundus autofluorescence
C. A central window defect on fluorescein angiography corresponding to the OCT area of disruption

answers.explanation: Solar retinopathy is classically associated with focal disruption of the ellipsoid zone and the retinal pigmented epithelium in some cases. This shows as a focal area of hypo-autofluorescence on fundus autofluorescence and a window defect due to hyper-transmission through the damaged retinal pigmented epithelium on fluorescein angiography.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Which of the following has shown proven benefit for the treatment of solar retinopathy?

answers.explanation: Unfortunately, no treatment has shown proven benefit for the treatment of solar retinopathy. Spontaneous recovery may occur within the first few months after the event, however central/paracentral scotomas and metamorphopsia may become permanent. If the defect is unilateral, some patients may be asymptomatic at presentation and solar retinopathy may present as an incidental finding and an OCT diagnosis. Most cases, however, are bilateral.

footer:
### Learning Objectives:

1. Recognize solar retinopathy as a differential diagnosis for focal disruption of the ellipsoid zone/RPE.

2. Laser pointer injury should also be included in the differential diagnosis of focal ellipsoid zone/RPE disruption.

3. Patient education and use of protective gear for sungazing is the most effective preventative strategy to reduce further vision loss.
